facts.text: On November 18, 1953, the Prohibition Officer, Madras City, and the Deputy Commissioner of Police made a search of premises No. 28, Thanikachala Chetty Street, Thyagarayanagar, Madras.

anchor.surface_text: Now, the facts are that on November 18, 1953, the Prohibition Officer, Madras City, and the Deputy Commissioner of Police made a search of premises No. 28, Thanikachala Chetty Street, Thyagarayanagar, Madras, and seized several bottles of foreign liquor and glasses containing whisky and soda.

facts.text: Several bottles of foreign liquor and glasses containing whisky and soda were seized from the premises.

anchor.surface_text: and seized several bottles of foreign liquor and glasses containing whisky and soda. The appellant, Lakshmanan Chettiar, was residing at the premises, and the other three appellants, A. S. Krishna, R. Venkataraman and V. S. Krishnaswamy, were found drinking from the glass tumblers.

facts.text: Appellant Lakshmanan Chettiar was residing at the premises No. 28, Thanikachala Chetty Street, Thyagarayanagar, Madras.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, Lakshmanan Chettiar, was residing at the premises, and the other three appellants, A. S. Krishna, R. Venkataraman and V. S. Krishnaswamy, were found drinking from the glass tumblers. All the four were immediately put under arrest and in due course charge-sheets were laid against them for offences under the Act.

facts.text: Lakshmanan Chettiar was charged under s. 4(1)(k) for allowing the acts in premises in his immediate possession, under s. 12 for abetment, and under s. 4(1)(a) for possession of more units than allowed under his permit.

anchor.surface_text: and Lakshmanan Chettiar was charged under s. 4  1   k  for allowing the above acts in premises in his immediate possession, a under s. 12 for abetment of the offences. He was also charged under s. 4  1   a  on the allegation that though he was a permit-holder, he was in possession of more units than were allowed under the permit, and that by reason of the proviso to that section, he had committed an offence under s. 4  1   a .

He was also charged under s. 4  1   a  on the allegation that though he was a permit-holder, he was in possession of more units than were allowed under the permit, and that by reason of the proviso to that section, he had committed an offence under s. 4  1   a . Immediately after service of summons, the appellants filed an application unders. 432 of the Criminal Procedure Code,

facts.text: Immediately after service of summons, the appellants filed an application under s. 432 of the Criminal Procedure Code contending that ss. 4(2) and 28 to 32 of the Act were unconstitutional.

anchor.surface_text: Immediately after service of summons, the appellants filed an application unders. 432 of the Criminal Procedure Code, wherein they contended that ss. 4 2  and 28 to 32 of the Act were repugnant to the provisions of the Constitution, and were therefore void, and prayed that the above question might be referred for the decision of the High Court.

facts.text: The Third Presidency Magistrate allowed the application and referred seven questions on the constitutionality of various sections of the Act to the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Third Presidency Magistrate, before whom the proceedings were pending, allowed the application, and referred to the High Court as many as seven questions on the constitutionality of various sections of the Act. This reference was heard by Rajamannar, C.J., and Umamaheswaram, J., who held, disagreeing with the appellants, that ss. 4 2  and 28 to 32 were valid,, and answered the reference against them.

facts.text: The reference was heard by Rajamannar, C.J., and Umamaheswaram, J., who held ss. 4(2) and 28 to 32 valid.

anchor.surface_text: This reference was heard by Rajamannar, C.J., and Umamaheswaram, J., who held, disagreeing with the appellants, that ss. 4 2  and 28 to 32 were valid,, and answered the reference against them. Against this judgment, the appellants have preferred the present appeals under Art. 136 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Appellants preferred present appeals under Art. 136 of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: if a statute is found in substance to relate to a topic within the competence of the legislature, it should be held to be intra vires, even though it might incidentally trench on topics not within its legislative competence

holdings.text: The Madras Prohibition Act is thus in its entirety a law within the exclusive competence of the Provincial Legislature, and the question of repugnancy under s. 107(1) does not arise.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pith and substance of Act is intoxicating liquors (Entry 31 List II Provincial); ss.4(2),28-32 ancillary provisions for enforcement, not encroaching on concurrent fields of evidence or criminal procedure; follows Privy Council and Federal Court precedents on pith and substance doctrine.

holdings.text: We are unable to see how s. 4(2) offends the requirement as to equality before law or the equal protection of laws.

anchor.surface_text: It is next companytended that the presumptions raised in s. 4 2  of the Act, are repugnant to Art. 14 of the Constitution, and that the section must accordingly be declared to have become void under Art. 13 1 . We are unable to see how s. 4 2  offends the requirement as to equality before law or the equal protection of laws.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Presumptions apply equally to all persons where foundational facts established; rational connection exists when read distributively; supported by US precedents upholding similar presumptions against due process/equal protection challenges.

holdings.text: In our opinion, the matters mentioned in s. 4(2) should be read distributively in relation to the offences mentioned in s. 4(1).

anchor.surface_text: We should add that the companystruction which the appellants seek to put on s. 4  2  that a person in possession of liquor companyld, under that section, be presumed to have companymitted an offence under s. 4 1   g  or that a person who is in possession of materials, implement or apparatus companyld be presumed to have companymitted offences under s. 4  1   a  and  j  is number companyrect. In our opinion, the matters mentioned in s. 4  2  should be read distributively in relation to the offences mentioned in s. 4 1 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation requires distributive reading of presumptions in s.4(2)(a)-(b) to specific offences in s.4(1)(a)-(k); ensures rational relation between fact proved and presumed guilt, avoiding arbitrariness.

holdings.text: It is therefore clear that even on the application of the due process clause, the presumptions laid down in s. 4(2) cannot be struck down as unconstitutional.

anchor.surface_text: It is therefore clear that even on the application of the due process clause, the presumptions laid down in s. 4 2  cannot be struck down as unconstitutional.
